title: Fasl-ı Cedid
text:
The Fasl-ı Cedid (The New Fasıl) was a musical ensemble of <a href="Ottoman%20classical%20music">Classical Turkish Music</a> operating within the organization of the <a href="Ottoman%20Imperial%20Orchestra">Ottoman Imperial Orchestra</a>, specializing in performances of <a href="Fas%C4%B1l">Fasıl</a>.
History.
The Fasl-ı Cedid was established by Santuri Hilmi Bey, a well-regarded musician in the Ottoman Imperial Court, with the endorsement of <a href="Mahmud%20II">Sultan Mahmud II</a>, as part of the <a href="Tanzimat">reforms</a> taking place in the Empire to westernize all government functions and institutions, including those relating to state-sponsored musical education.
Structure.
The ensemble was typically made up of <a href="ney">ney</a>s, <a href="flute">flute</a>s, and <a href="mandolin">mandolin</a>s, variously complemented by <a href="violin">violin</a>s, <a href="violoncello">violoncello</a>s, <a href="lute">lute</a>s, <a href="guitar">guitar</a>s, <a href="trombone">trombone</a>s and <a href="castanet">castanet</a>s. More traditional <a href="baglama">saz</a> elements such as <a href="oud">oud</a>s, <a href="ney">ney</a>s, <a href="Kanun%20%28instrument%29">kanun</a>s and <a href="zill">zill</a>s generally accompanied these instruments.
The compositions performed featured <a href="makam">makam</a>s closer to the melodic structures, keys and chords as defined by a western understanding of scale, i.e. <a href="major%20scale">major</a> and <a href="minor%20scale">minor</a>, and generally were of <a href="pe%C5%9Frev">peşrev</a>, <a href="saz%20sem%C3%A2%27%C3%AE">saz semâ'î</a>, <a href="canzone">canzone</a>, <a href="k%C3%B6%C3%A7ek%C3%A7e">köçekçe</a> and <a href="oyun%20havas%C4%B1">oyun havası</a> performances.
